title: AI / Open Q & A with Coach Keith - Medical AI Models and Cloud Hosting

chapters.title: Introduction and Finding the Medical AI Model

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Let's see if I can find my Perplexity window buried among a bajillion windows.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: I read some news today, maybe from The Rundown AI or a similar publication, about a new medical AI model.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: I vaguely remember it was about Gemini or MedGamma in a medical setting, but I wasn't sure which company was behind it—Meta, Alphabet, or Facebook.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: After searching, I found that Google just released new open source AI models for healthcare called MedGamma.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Let me organize my screen a bit and then we can dive into it together.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Since I've done some medical work before, I thought you might find this interesting.

chapters.title: Overview of MedGamma Model and Medical QA

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: MedGamma 27B can process both medical text and images, which is pretty cool.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: It achieved some score on Med QA, which tests foundational medical knowledge but not necessarily the kind of knowledge a doctor applies during a patient visit.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: It's great to see a much smaller model achieving similar quality to a bigger one.

segments.speaker: Student
segments.text: Do they have libraries for images or client interactions where you can test your AI and compare it to others, like with image matching for different skin tones?

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: That's a good question. Let me check if there's a website hosting leaderboards for Med QA or if evaluation is done by researchers or uploaded by them.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Med QA and PubMed QA track diverse medical datasets, but these are mostly text-based quizzes similar to medical class or board exam questions.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: They might not test image capabilities, so doing well on these might not indicate how well the model handles images.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Also, these evaluations don't assess bias or demographic fairness.

chapters.title: Exploring Google's Medical AI Announcement and Multimodal Capabilities

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Let's look at Google's announcement. They have a research blog with a full paper and a shorter blog post that's easier to read.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: MedGamma complements previously released models by adding support for complex multimodal inputs—meaning multiple types like text plus images or video.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Longitudinal electronic health record interpretation is important because patients often have complex histories across multiple care settings.

segments.speaker: Student
segments.text: Are they using 'multimodal' in a data science sense or a medical sense? Like combining X-rays and other medical data?

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: I think here they mean multimodal in the data science sense, but we'll see as we go on.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: They have a second new model, but we won't focus on that now.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Multimodal clinical reasoning might mean the medical sense, combining different viewpoints like from a GP or oncologist.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: They are trying to integrate imaging from radiology, text, and electronic health records, which is a loose standard format for health records.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: You can't just give it a CT scan it hasn't seen before; it needs to have seen many examples and associated physician interpretations.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Radiology report generation is common; some companies focus on translating radiologist terminology into terms GPs can understand safely.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: EHR summarization and retrieval is important because patients can have years of notes no one has time to read.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: In an unblinded study, 81% of generated chest X-ray reports were judged sufficiently accurate to result in similar patient management.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: However, they don't specify the risk level in the 19% where it differed—whether it could lead to adverse effects or just suboptimal approaches.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Accuracy numbers are a good starting point but not sufficient to decide if this can be used in medical practice.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: MedGamma achieves competitive performance on medical image classification tests, which is a first step.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Image classification might detect diseases like dermatology conditions, but without safety and error analysis, we can't consider it for real use yet.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: They show a chart of Med QA score versus cost, indicating better quality for cost, but it doesn't tell us enough for medical use decisions.

segments.speaker: Student
segments.text: What does the cost refer to? CPU cycles, licensing, or hardware?

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: The cost is dollars per million tokens on a log scale, mostly for text processing, focusing on operating costs like power and cooling for GPUs.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: It's not about buying hardware but the ongoing power and cooling costs, usually paid through SaaS systems.

chapters.title: Cloud Hosting, Privacy, and Security Considerations

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: People like us won't host these models ourselves; companies might rent Google or AWS servers and charge API usage fees.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Google hosts their models on their systems, profiting from compute and model overhead.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: If you use MedGamma 27B, you'd likely use Google Cloud's Vertex AI rather than running it on your own hardware or AWS.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Google has expertise in efficient hosting and autoscaling, which is a lot of programming work even for smaller models.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: If you trust Google Cloud's privacy and security, that's the best path.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: In healthcare, companies try to minimize the number of vendors with access to patient data, even beyond legal requirements like HIPAA.

segments.speaker: Student
segments.text: Could you obfuscate data to prevent tying it to specific people while still using it?

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Yes, but it's tough. Some medical images have identifiers embedded, so you have to clip or anonymize carefully.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Text data also needs thorough anonymization to prevent patient identification, especially in case of data breaches.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Different companies have different risk tolerances, but a layered approach to privacy and security is best.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Autoscaling is complex. If you have few users, one server is fine, but if usage spikes, you need to scale up dynamically.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Autoscaling means creating the right number of servers for the load and scaling down when demand decreases to save costs.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Google's autoscaling for MedGamma is reliable and tested, and it's best to use their solution rather than implement your own.

segments.speaker: Student
segments.text: Is autoscaling part of data science?

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: No, most autoscaling uses simple rules like CPU load thresholds to add or remove servers.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Simple rules are easy to test, understand, and trace. Using machine learning for autoscaling can be risky and costly if it goes wrong.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Large companies like Google can predict usage patterns and pre-scale accordingly, but small companies face unpredictable loads.

chapters.title: Integration and Cost Management in Cloud AI Solutions

segments.speaker: Other
segments.text: From an end-user perspective, integrating AI with Google Cloud allows setting spend and resource thresholds to avoid overspending.

segments.speaker: Other
segments.text: Google handles security and many complex problems within their cloud, making integration smoother than building your own environment.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Yes, Google Cloud lets you set actual cost limits and cut off usage if thresholds are exceeded, with notifications.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: In large organizations like Mayo Clinic, dedicated staff monitor spend limits, but small companies wear many hats.

segments.speaker: Student
segments.text: I'm a bit weak on building APIs to interface with AI solutions. Conceptually, I understand sending inputs and receiving outputs.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: API usage is fairly basic: you send input data and receive output. Sometimes outputs are structured rather than just text or images.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Autoscaling is challenging because loading large models into memory takes time, unlike simple web services.

chapters.title: Training vs Inference in AI Models and Use Cases

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: AI has training and inference phases. Training is expensive and involves learning from large datasets, like the entire internet.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Inference is applying the trained model to specific inputs, like a patient's medical record and images, to generate outputs.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: MedGamma 27B interprets multimodal inputs and generates outputs consistent with its training and the input context.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Traditional machine learning models are narrow and task-specific, like classifying dermatology images, and less adaptable.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Narrow models allow specific tests for fairness and quality, but general models like MedGamma cover many use cases with broader but shallower testing.

segments.speaker: Student
segments.text: Would you combine general and specialized models, loading specific data for particular issues like dermatology?

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Yes, patients come with specific problems, and models can incorporate relevant data, but covering all medical specialties deeply is challenging.

chapters.title: Medical Imaging and Preventative Care Discussion

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: There was a 60 Minutes segment about AI analyzing oncology X-rays, finding some cases missed by professionals.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: The challenge is whether AI errors could lead to harmful patient outcomes.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: I wonder why whole-body scans aren't routine. Some friends found cancer incidentally during scans for other issues.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Whole-body scans are available but expensive and not covered by insurance, and often considered not useful because findings are rare.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: MRI scans are safer than CT scans because they don't use ionizing radiation, but cost and time are barriers.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: I wish medicine used technology more proactively for prevention, especially with AI helping analyze high-resolution imaging.

segments.speaker: Student
segments.text: I want to address that if we have time.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Sure, go ahead.

chapters.title: Risks of Diagnostic Procedures and Regulatory Perspectives

segments.speaker: Student
segments.text: The FDA once classified many food additives as safe, but later found some to be carcinogenic.

segments.speaker: Student
segments.text: Similarly, diagnostic procedures like X-rays have risks; early X-ray technicians wore badges and lead aprons due to radiation exposure.

segments.speaker: Student
segments.text: As technology advances, we discover new risks, so use of diagnostic tools requires discretion.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Non-ionizing radiation like MRI is much safer, but all energy applied to the body carries some risk.

segments.speaker: Student
segments.text: Everything is a balance; even driving to the hospital has risks, and sedentary lifestyles are dangerous too.

chapters.title: Cloud AI Hosting Options and Global Data Regulations

segments.speaker: Student
segments.text: Are there similar AI models hosted on AWS or in other countries like China that might be cheaper?

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: AWS hosts many AI models through Bedrock, similar to Google's Vertex AI, but last I checked, no specific medical AI model was available there.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: For medical use, start with platforms your organization already has agreements with, like AWS, then consider others.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Security, budgeting, and vendor approval take more time than switching platforms.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Hosting in cheaper locations hasn't proven effective yet; prices are generally pegged to US rates worldwide.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Some startups try moving servers near cheap power sources to reduce costs, but big players are also investing in power generation.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Microsoft is exploring nuclear power for data centers, which is cost-effective long term despite high upfront costs.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: China has strict data regulations requiring separate data centers, so data hosting there is complex.

chapters.title: Session Wrap-up and API Learning Resources

segments.speaker: Student
segments.text: This is my first time attending. I have a background in development and business analysis but have been unemployed for 20 months.

segments.speaker: Student
segments.text: Is there API documentation I can study to refresh my memory for job applications? Also, what does a data custodian do?

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: APIs vary by system, so experience with multiple APIs is best. I can share some beginner-friendly guides and examples.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Data custodian roles are like digital librarians managing data access and security.

segments.speaker: Student
segments.text: I also want to know if AI can rewrite or edit Word documents online, similar to macros I used to create.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: You can use ChatGPT for writing tasks by providing a draft and instructions. Google Docs and Microsoft Word have some AI editing features built-in.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Microsoft partners with OpenAI, so their AI features use similar underlying models with specialized prompts.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: A common use case is AI helping to spot-check emails before sending to avoid regrettable messages.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: I will look up more resources for next time and share the chat transcript.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Thanks, everyone. Sorry for going a bit long. I have some homework of my own now.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: I hope you all have a good evening and a great weekend.

segments.speaker: Student
segments.text: Thank you very much.

processing_notes: Removed filler words and speech disfluencies for clarity.

Identified speakers as Host, Student, or Other based on context.
Segmented transcript into chapters by topic and conversation flow.
Classified chapters by type: admin, explanation, qa, and discussion.
Preserved all substantive content and chronological order.
Transformed speech into clear, coherent prose with complete sentences.
